name: Proper Distance
description: The formal definition of the proper distance between two objects, computed by integrating the radial component of the Robertson-Walker metric. R is the radial coordinate, a(t) is the scale factor, and k is the curvature parameter

name: Proper Distance and Co-moving Distance Relation
description: The relationship between proper distance and co-moving distance at cosmic time t, where dc is the co-moving distance which does not depend on cosmic time

name: Present Proper Distance Equals Co-moving Distance
description: When the scale factor is conventionally set to unity at the present time (a(t0)=1), the present proper distance equals the co-moving distance

name: Robertson-Walker Metric for Null Geodesics
description: The Robertson-Walker metric for photons travelling along null geodesics (ds^2 = 0) in the radial direction

name: Metric Separation of Time and Radial Terms
description: Separation of the Robertson-Walker metric terms that depend on time t from those that depend on radial coordinate r

name: Light Travel Integral
description: Integral form relating the time and radial coordinate for photons emitted at time tem and detected at time tobs, travelling from r=R to r=0

name: Proper Distance from Cosmic Time Integral
description: Expression for the present proper distance in terms of an integral over cosmic time, relating directly to measurements of cosmic time

name: Horizon Distance Integral (Matter-Dominated)
description: The integral for computing the horizon distance in a flat, matter-dominated universe where a(t) = (t/t0)^(2/3)

name: Proper Distance in Terms of Redshift
description: Expression for the present proper distance as an integral over redshift, where E(z) encodes the dependence on cosmological parameters. This directly relates dp to observable redshift

name: E(z) Function
description: The dimensionless function E(z) that appears in the proper distance integral, encoding the dependence on density parameters

name: Hubble-Lemaître Law (Low Redshift)
description: At low redshifts, the proper distance integral reduces to the linear Hubble-Lemaître law relating redshift to present proper distance

name: Luminosity Distance
description: Definition of the luminosity distance, which relates the intrinsic luminosity L of a standard candle to its observed flux F

name: Luminosity Distance and Proper Distance Relation
description: In a flat universe, the luminosity distance is related to the present proper distance by a factor of (1+z), accounting for cosmic expansion effects on observed flux

name: Angular Diameter Distance
description: Definition of the angular diameter distance, relating the physical size l of a standard rod to its observed angular size theta (in radians)

name: Angular Diameter Distance and Proper Distance Relation
description: In a flat universe, the angular diameter distance is related to the present proper distance by a factor of 1/(1+z)

name: Angular Size at Emission Time
description: The angular size of a standard rod as seen by an observer at the time of photon emission, where the proper distance was dp(tem)

name: Physical Length from Angular Size
description: Expression for the physical length l of a standard rod in terms of observed angle, proper distance, and scale factor

name: Angular Diameter Distance Equals Emission Proper Distance
description: The angular diameter distance equals the proper distance at the time of emission, which was smaller due to the smaller scale factor

name: Surface Brightness Redshift Dependence
description: The observed surface brightness of objects decreases rapidly with redshift as (1+z)^(-4), making high-redshift objects difficult to detect

name: Stellar Parallax Distance
description: Calculation of distance using stellar parallax, where db is the baseline distance (Earth's orbital radius) and theta is half the parallax angle

name: Recession Velocity
description: The recession velocity of a star due to cosmic expansion, expressed in terms of the co-moving distance, scale factor, and Hubble parameter

name: Scale Factor-Redshift Relation (Rearranged)
description: The relationship between scale factor and redshift, rearranged to isolate z

name: Low-z Approximation for Redshift
description: Approximate expression for redshift at low values using Taylor expansion of the scale factor around t0

name: Recession Velocity Approximation
description: Approximate recession velocity for nearby objects where stellar parallax can be measured (z ~ 10^-5)

name: Classical Cepheid Period-Luminosity Relation
description: The relationship between the mean absolute magnitude of a Classical Cepheid star and its pulsation period P in days, with empirically determined coefficients A and B

name: Distance Modulus
description: The relationship between apparent magnitude m, absolute magnitude M, and luminosity distance dL in parsecs

name: Hubble Distance
description: A characteristic cosmological length scale that sets an approximate size for the observable Universe

name: Hubble Time
description: A characteristic cosmological time scale that provides an approximate age for the Universe (though not equal to the true age in general)

name: Reduced Hubble Constant Squared
description: Definition of h^2, used when measuring baryon and dark matter densities as multiples of this quantity

name: Apparent Magnitude Expression
description: Expression for the apparent magnitude of a Type Ia supernova in terms of absolute magnitude M, Hubble constant H0 (in km/s/Mpc), and luminosity distance dL (in Mpc)

name: Hubble Constant from Distance Modulus
description: Expression for computing the Hubble constant from corrected apparent magnitudes and the true absolute magnitude of Type Ia supernovae

name: Low-Redshift Approximation Variable
description: A measurable variable that can be computed directly from observations of Type Ia supernovae at low redshift, where H0dL ≈ cz

name: Luminosity Distance Expansion (Second Order)
description: Second-order approximation for the luminosity distance at moderate redshifts (accurate to 1% for z < 0.2), including the deceleration parameter q0

name: Intercept M Definition
description: Definition of the intercept parameter M that combines absolute magnitude with the Hubble constant, allowing cosmological parameters to be measured without knowing H0

name: Low-Redshift Magnitude-Redshift Relation
description: Linear relationship between apparent magnitude and log(cz) at low redshift, used to estimate the intercept M

name: Uncertainty Propagation (Unary Function)
description: Standard formula for propagating measurement uncertainty through a function of a single variable

name: Uncertainty Propagation (Binary Function)
description: Standard formula for propagating measurement uncertainties through a function of two uncorrelated variables

name: Distance Relations Summary
description: Summary of the relationships between present proper distance, luminosity distance, and angular diameter distance in a spatially flat universe
